question: Explain the basic rule of Accretion/Dilution: If Acquirer P/E is 20x and Target P/E is 10x, and deal is 100% Stock, is it accretive? Why? (Cost of Stock vs Yield of Target).
Calculate cost of debt impact: Acquirer uses 100% Cash. Cash interest foregone is 2% (after-tax 1.5%). Target Earnings Yield (E/P) is 10%. Is this accretive? What is the breakeven P/E?

Model synergy impact: Deal is dilutive by $0.10 EPS pre-synergies. Acquirer expects $100M synergies. Share count 500M. Tax rate 25%. After-tax synergies = $75M. Per share = $0.15. Is deal accretive net of synergies?
Analyze P/E relativity: Acquirer P/E 15x. Target P/E 20x. Deal 100% Stock. Is it accretive? Why does paying a higher multiple dilute shareholders?
Calculate breakeven synergies: Acquirer EPS $2.00 (500M shares). Target Net Income $50M. Purchase Price $1B (100% debt at 5%). Deal is dilutive. How much pre-tax synergy is needed to break even?
Compare Cash vs Stock: Acquirer P/E 10x (Yield 10%). Cost of Debt 5% (After-tax 3.75%). Target P/E 15x (Yield 6.6%). Which currency (Cash or Stock) makes the deal accretive?
Model write-up amortization: Asset Deal creates $500M Intangible Assets (amortizable over 10 years). Annual D&A increases $50M. Tax rate 25%. What is the Cash EPS vs GAAP EPS impact?
Explain the "Foregone Interest" concept: When using cash on balance sheet, you lose interest income. Why is the cost of cash usually lower than the cost of debt? (Risk-free rate vs Spread).
Analyze exchange ratio fixed vs floating: Fixed Ratio (1.5 shares) vs Fixed Value ($50). If Acquirer stock drops 20% before close, who bears the risk in each? How does this affect accretion?
Calculate pro-forma share count: Acquirer share price $100. Target Equity Value $1B. Deal 50% Stock / 50% Cash. Exchange ratio? How many new shares issued?

Model "Double Dilution": Target has convertible bonds and options. In an acquisition, these convert/vest. How do you calculate the fully diluted purchase price and share count for the accretion model?
Analyze EPS vs FCF Accretion: A deal is EPS Dilutive (due to huge D&A write-up) but FCF Accretive (due to tax shield). Which metric should the CFO focus on?
Explain "Contribution Analysis": Target contributes 30% of Earnings but ownership is only 20% of Pro-Forma Entity. Is the deal accretive? (Accretive if Contribution % > Ownership %).

Calculate acquisition premium limit: Acquirer P/E 20x. Target P/E 15x. Synergies 0. How much premium can Acquirer pay (raising Target P/E) before deal becomes dilutive? (Breakeven P/E = Acquirer P/E).
Model treasury stock method in M&A: Target options are "cashed out" at intrinsic value. Does this increase purchase price? Or just reduce net cash payment?
Compare Asset Sale vs Stock Sale: Buyer prefers Asset Sale (Step-up basis, avoid liabilities). Seller prefers Stock Sale (Lower tax, clean exit). Why?
Explain Section 338(h)(10) election: A Stock Sale that is treated as an Asset Sale for tax purposes. Why would both parties agree? (Buyer gets tax shield, Seller gets premium to cover extra tax).
Understand Earnouts: Bridge valuation gap. Seller wants $100M, Buyer offers $80M. Compromise: $80M upfront + $20M if EBITDA hits $15M. What are the risks for the Seller? (Buyer manipulation).

Analyze Locked Box vs Completion Accounts: Locked Box (Price fixed at historical date, cash leakage prevention) vs Completion Accounts (Price adjusted for working capital/net debt at close). Which provides certainty?
Explain "No-Shop" vs "Go-Shop": No-Shop protects buyer. Go-Shop allows seller to find better offer for 30 days. When is Go-Shop used? (PE take-privates to prove fairness).
Model Break-up Fee: Target accepts higher bid. Must pay original buyer 3% break fee. How does this affect the effective price for the new bidder?
Understand Material Adverse Change (MAC): Buyer wants to walk away due to "MAC". Covid-19 was argued as MAC. Why is it hard to invoke? (High legal bar, carve-outs).
Analyze Net Working Capital (NWC) peg: Purchase price assumes "Normal" NWC. If actual NWC at close is higher, Buyer pays more. Why? (Buyer gets more liquid assets).
Explain Deferred Tax Liability (DTL) in M&A: Write-up of assets creates book/tax difference. DTL is created on balance sheet. Is this real debt? (No, usually indefinite deferral).
Structure a "Reverse Morris Trust": Spin-off combined with merger. Tax-free. Requirements (Parent must own >50%). Why is this popular for shedding divisions?

Compare Triangular Mergers: Forward (Target merges into Sub, Target dies) vs Reverse (Sub merges into Target, Target survives). Why is Reverse Triangular preferred? (Maintains Target's contracts/licenses).
Model Contingent Value Rights (CVR): BioTech M&A. $10/share + CVR for $5 if FDA approval. How do you value the CVR? (Probability weighting).
Explain "Social Issues" in merger of equals: CEO role, Board split, HQ location. Why do these kill deals more often than price?
Analyze "Double Trigger" acceleration: Employee stock vests only if (1) Change of Control AND (2) Fired. Why do buyers insist on this vs Single Trigger? (Retention).
Structure consideration for tax: 50% Cash (Taxable) / 50% Stock (Tax-deferred). How does the "Continuity of Interest" rule apply?
Explain "Control Premium": Public company trades at $100. Acquirer pays $130 (30% premium). Why? (Synergies + Control rights).
Calculate Implied Synergy Value: Premium paid = $300M. Integration costs = $50M. Synergies must be worth > $350M for deal to create value. PV of Synergies calculation.
Use Precedent Transactions: Why are Precedent Multiples usually higher than Trading Multiples? (Include control premium).
Analyze "Affordability" (LBO Floor): Financial sponsor can pay max 10x EBITDA (based on leverage/IRR). Strategic buyer can pay 12x (Synergies). Why does Strategic usually win?
Explain Fairness Opinion: Investment Bank certifies price is "Fair". Legal defense for Board. Does "Fair" mean "Highest Possible"? (No).
Model "Sum of the Parts" (SOTP) in breakup: Conglomerate trades at 8x. Divisions trade at 12x, 10x, 6x. Breakup value = 11x. Activist thesis.
Adjust for "Change of Control" costs: Bankers fees (1%), Legal, Severance, Debt breakage. These add 5-10% to effective purchase price.
Analyze "Footprint" synergy: Buying competitor closes local branch. Revenue retention 90%. Cost savings 100%. Valuation impact.
Calculate "Distributable Cash Flow" for dividend model: In M&A, can the Target's cash flow support the Acquirer's dividend? Accretion to "Cash Flow per Share".
Value a "NOL Shell": Company has no ops, just $500M NOLs. Buyer injects profitable business. Value of Shell = PV of tax savings. Section 382 limitations.
Model "Revenue Synergies": Cross-selling Product A to Customer Base B. Much harder to value than Cost Synergies. How much do you discount? (Usually 50%+ discount).
Explain "Exchange Ratio Collar": Fixed ratio, but if Acquirer stock drops <$80, ratio adjusts to maintain $ value. Limits risk for Seller.
Analyze "Merger of Equals" (MOE) valuation: Usually low/zero premium. Stock-for-stock. "At market". Why do shareholders accept no premium? (Share in future synergies).
Value "In-Process R&D" (IPR&D): Asset deal. Capitalize R&D. Indefinite life intangible. No amortization? Impairment testing.
Model "Purchase Price Allocation" (PPA): Allocating $1B excess purchase price to: (1) Write-up PP&E, (2) Intangibles, (3) Goodwill. How does this affect future EPS?
Explain the Auction Process: Broad Auction (50 buyers) vs Targeted (5 buyers) vs Proprietary (1 buyer). Trade-off: Speed/Confidentiality vs Price maximization.
Understand the NDA (Non-Disclosure Agreement): Standstill provision (Buyer cannot buy stock hostilely for 1 year). Non-solicit (Cannot hire employees).
Explain the Teaser vs CIM: Teaser (Anonymous, 2 pages) vs Confidential Information Memorandum (Detailed, 50 pages). When are they sent?
Analyze the Letter of Intent (LOI): Non-binding (mostly). Exclusivity (Binding). Price range. Structure. Why is Exclusivity the key negotiation point for Buyer?
Understand the Data Room: Due diligence phase. VDR (Virtual Data Room). Who gets access? (Bankers, Lawyers, Accountants).
Explain "Gun Jumping": Antitrust rule. Competitors cannot coordinate prices/customers *before* closing. Clean Teams used for synergy planning.
Analyze HSR Filing (Hart-Scott-Rodino): Antitrust review. Deals >$100M (approx). waiting period 30 days. Second Request (Deep dive).
Understand "Fiduciary Out": Target Board can accept a "Superior Proposal" even after signing merger agreement (paying break fee). Required by Delaware law (Revlon duties).
Explain "Definitive Agreement" (DA): Representations & Warranties. Indemnification. Conditions to Close.
Analyze "Sandbagging" provision: Buyer knows about a breach of warranty *before* close but closes anyway, then sues for indemnity. Pro-sandbagging (Buyer friendly) vs Anti-sandbagging.
Explain "Bring Down" certificate: Reps & Warranties must be true at signing AND at closing. If not true at closing (e.g. factory burned down), Buyer can walk.
Understand Reps & Warranties Insurance (RWI): Buyer buys insurance policy to cover breaches. Seller liability capped at 1% (deductible). Replaces Escrow.
Analyze "Specific Performance": Legal remedy. Forces the party to close the deal (not just pay damages). Critical for Sellers if Buyer gets cold feet.
Explain "Hell or High Water" clause: Antitrust risk allocation. Buyer must do *anything* (sell assets, divest) to get regulatory approval.
Model timeline risk: Deal takes 12 months to close (Antitrust). Value of money (TVM). Ticking Fee (Price increases per month of delay).
Hostile Takeover: Target Board says no. Acquirer goes directly to shareholders (Tender Offer). "Bear Hug" letter.
Poison Pill: Shareholder Rights Plan. If Acquirer buys >15%, all other shareholders get rights to buy cheap stock. Dilutes Acquirer. How does it force negotiation?
Proxy Fight: Activist/Acquirer runs a slate of directors to replace the Board. If they win, new Board approves the deal.
Leveraged Recap as defense: Target borrows massive debt to pay special dividend. Makes Target less attractive (high debt) and gives value to shareholders.
White Knight: Target finds a friendly buyer to save them from Hostile Raider. Lock-up assets?
Crown Jewel Defense: Target sells its most valuable asset to a third party. Makes Target undesirable.
Pac-Man Defense: Target turns around and bids for the Acquirer.
Squeeze-Out Merger: Acquirer owns 90% (Short form). Can force the remaining 10% to sell without a vote.
Appraisal Rights: Dissenting shareholders petition court for "Fair Value" (which might be > Deal Price). Risk for Acquirer.
Tender Offer vs Merger Vote: Tender (Direct to holders, faster, needs 50%+). Vote (Board approved, slower, needs shareholder meeting). Two-Step Merger (Tender -> Squeeze out).
Stapled Financing: Seller's bank offers debt package to potential buyers. Sets a floor on valuation/leverage. Conflict of interest?
Go-Shop with "Matching Rights": Buyer has right to match any superior offer. Winner's Curse mitigation?
Management Buyout (MBO): Management teams up with PE. Board forms Special Committee (Independent) to evaluate. Why? (Conflict of Interest).
PIPE (Private Investment in Public Equity) backing M&A: Acquirer needs cash to close. Sells stock to Hedge Fund at discount. "Change of Control" PIPE.
SPAC Merger (De-SPAC): Target merges with public shell. Redemption rate risk. PIPEs to fill the hole.
Explain Chapter 7 vs Chapter 11: Chapter 7 (Liquidation, Trustee sells assets, company dies) vs Chapter 11 (Reorganization, Debtor in Possession, company survives). Why choose 11?
Understand "Automatic Stay": The moment bankruptcy is filed, all litigation/collection stops. Why is this the most powerful tool? (Breathing room).
Explain "Debtor in Possession" (DIP): Management stays in control during Ch 11. They are fiduciaries for the *Estate* (Creditors), not Shareholders.
Define "The Estate": All assets of the company become property of the Estate. Creditors have claims against the Estate.
Explain "Executory Contracts": Leases, Supplier contracts. Debtor can Assume (Keep) or Reject (Break). Why is Rejection powerful? (Retailer closing stores).
Analyze "DIP Financing": New money lent to bankrupt company. Super-priority (paid before pre-petition debt). Why do lenders provide it? (High fees, control).
Understand "Critical Vendor" motions: Paying certain pre-petition creditors (suppliers) immediately to keep business running. Exception to equality rule.
Explain "363 Sale": Sale of assets "free and clear" of liens. Faster than Plan of Reorganization. Stalking Horse bidder.
Analyze "Pre-Pack" vs "Free-Fall": Pre-packaged bankruptcy (Plan agreed before filing, fast) vs Free-Fall (No plan, chaotic).
Explain "Fraudulent Conveyance": Looking back 2 years. Did company transfer assets for less than fair value while insolvent? Clawback.
Understand "Preferences": Payments made to specific creditors 90 days before filing. Can be clawed back to share equally.
Model "Equitable Subordination": Court pushes a creditor down the stack because of bad behavior (e.g., Insider lending).
Analyze "Substantive Consolidation": Merging assets/liabilities of subsidiaries into one pot. Ignores corporate veil. Bad for structually senior lenders.
Explain "Make-Whole" claims: Lenders demand future interest payments upon repayment. Is bankruptcy a "voluntary" prepayment? (Litigation topic).
Understand "Credit Bidding": Secured lender can bid their debt (face value) in a 363 sale. Prevents lowball bids.
List the Waterfall of Claims: (1) Secured Debt, (2) Admin Claims (Lawyers/DIP), (3) Priority (Taxes/Wages), (4) Unsecured Debt (Bonds/Trade), (5) Subordinated, (6) Equity.
Explain "Secured" claim: Backed by collateral (Asset). Claim is secured up to the *value* of the asset. Deficiency is Unsecured.
Understand "Deficiency Claim": Loan $100M. Collateral value $80M. Secured Claim $80M. Unsecured Claim $20M.
Explain "Administrative Claim": Expenses of preserving the estate (Lawyers, Bankers, Rent post-petition). Paid 100% in cash to exit Ch 11.
Analyze "Structural Subordination": Debt at HoldCo vs Debt at OpCo. OpCo debt gets paid from OpCo assets first. HoldCo gets residual equity of OpCo.
Explain "Contractual Subordination": Junior agrees to wait until Senior is paid. "Turnover" provision.
Understand "Lien Priority": First Lien vs Second Lien on same collateral. Waterfall within the Secured class.
Analyze "Unsecured vs Trade": Usually pari passu. But Critical Vendor motions might pay Trade first. Bondholders get angry.
Explain "1114 Claims": Retiree benefits. Priority status? Often negotiated.
Model "Value Breaks": Determine where the value runs out. If EV = $500M. Secured $300M. Unsecured $400M. Value breaks in the Unsecureds. Secured = 100%. Unsecured = 50%. Equity = 0.
Explain "Fulcrum Security": The class where the value breaks. They control the restructuring because they become the new owners (Equity).
Analyze "Gift Plan": Senior lenders give value to Equity (skipping Junior debt) to get a quick deal. Is this legal? (Absolute Priority Rule violation?).
Model "Rights Offering" in Rx: New money equity injection offered to creditors. Backstop fees. Dilutes non-participants.
Explain "Roll-Up": DIP loan pays off Pre-Petition Senior Debt. "Creeping Roll-Up". Better treatment for Senior.
Analyze "Priming": DIP loan takes a senior lien over existing secured lenders. Requires "Adequate Protection" for existing lenders.
Calculate Recovery Rate: Claim $100. Distribution $40. Recovery 40%. Trading price of bond usually reflects expected recovery.
Model Debt-for-Equity Swap: Swap $100M Unsecured Bond for 100% of New Equity. Pro-forma leverage drops.
Calculate "Yield to Maturity" (YTM) for distressed: Price 50. Coupon 8. Maturity 2 years. YTM is massive (e.g. 40%). But "Yield to Worst" or "Yield to Maturity" is misleading if default is certain.
Explain "Current Yield" vs YTM: Coupon / Price. Cash flow measure.
Model "Reinstatement": Cure defaults, leave debt in place (original maturity/rate). Good if original rate is low.
Calculate "Stripped Yield": Value of the bond considering collateral vs unsecured portion.
Model "New Value" exception: Old Equity puts in new money to keep ownership. Market test required.
Analyze "Cramdown" Math: Impaired class votes No. Plan confirmed anyway if "Fair and Equitable". No class junior gets paid.
Calculate Voting Threshold: Chapter 11 Plan needs 2/3 in Amount AND 1/2 in Number of voting creditors. Blocking position = 33.4% of debt.
Model "Liquidation Analysis": Best Interest Test. Creditors must get at least what they would get in Chapter 7 liquidation.
Analyze "Feasibility Test": Can the reorganized company survive? Interest coverage, leverage ratios post-emergence.
Value "Litigation Trust": Assets transferred to a trust to sue directors/auditors. Recovery flows to creditors. Option value.
Calculate "Warrants" for junior classes: Out-of-the-money warrants given to old equity as a "tip" to stop fighting. Valuation using Black-Scholes.
Model "Tax Attributes" (NOL) preservation: 382(l)(5) bankruptcy exception. Requires creditors to own 50% of new equity. Value of NOLs.
Analyze "Default Interest": Pre-petition rate vs Default rate (usually +2%). Does the claim include default interest? (Solvent debtor exception).
"Loan-to-Own" strategy: Buy distressed debt at 50 cents. Convert to equity in Ch 11. Own company at 50% cost basis.
Stalking Horse Bid: The initial bidder in a 363 sale. Sets the floor. Gets break-up fee if outbid. Advantages/Disadvantages.
"Free and Clear" order: 363 Sale strips liens. Buyer gets clean title. Liens attach to the *proceeds* (Cash).
Distressed Valuation: Multiples are irrelevant. DCF is hard. Liquidation value is floor. Fulcrum security trading value implies EV.
Purchasing Claims: Buyer buys trade claims to get a seat on the UCC (Unsecured Creditors Committee). Influence process.
"Naked" Credit Bid: Can lender credit bid only the *secured* portion? Or full face value?
"Gifting" in Sale: Senior lender lets Buyer pay some cash to Unsecureds to grease the wheels.
Intellectual Property rights in 363: Licenses? Can they be assigned?
Employee contracts: Does Buyer assume Successor Liability? Usually no in 363, yes in Merger.
"Sub-Plan" M&A: Sale executed as part of the Plan of Reorganization (not 363). Slower, but allows more complex structuring (debt reinstatement).
Regulatory approvals in Distressed M&A: Antitrust "Failing Firm" defense. Hard to prove.
WARN Act liability: Mass layoffs requiring 60 days notice. Priority claim. Does Buyer inherit?
Cure Costs: To assume a contract (Lease), Debtor must pay all arrears (Cure). Buyer usually pays this. Adds to purchase price.
Designation of Rights: Debtor can block a "Bad Faith" bidder?
MOIC in Distressed: High risk. Target 2.0x-3.0x in 2 years. High IRR due to speed.
Pre-Petition Planning: Drawing down the Revolver before filing ("Cash Hoarding"). Strategy.
RSA (Restructuring Support Agreement): Contract between Debtor and Key Creditors to support a specific plan. Locks in the vote.
UCC (Unsecured Creditors Committee): Fees paid by Debtor. Watchdog. Can sue for fraudulent conveyance.
"Death Trap" provision: Plan offers Class X a recovery IF they vote Yes. If they vote No, they get nothing (or less). Coercive?
Third Party Releases: Plan releases Non-Debtors (e.g. PE Sponsor, Directors) from liability. "Purdue Pharma" controversy.
"Toggle Plan": Plan A (Reorg) vs Plan B (Sale). Debtor runs parallel processes.
Cross-Border Insolvency: Chapter 15. Recognition of foreign proceeding. COMI (Center of Main Interest).
Municipal Bankruptcy: Chapter 9. Detroit/Puerto Rico. Different rules (States' rights). Cannot liquidate a city.
Mass Tort Bankruptcy: Asbestos/Opioids. Section 524(g) Trust. Channeling injunction. Future claimants.
Make-Whole Litigation: "Ultra Petroleum". Is make-whole disallowed as "unmatured interest"? Circuit split.
"Up-Tier" Exchange: J.Crew / Serta. Company issues *new* Super-Priority debt to *some* existing lenders, priming the others. "Lender on Lender violence".
"Drop-Down" Transaction: J.Crew Trapdoor. Transfer IP to an Unrestricted Subsidiary. Raise new debt on that IP. Leaves old lenders empty-handed.
"Double Dip" structure: Creditor lends to Sub, guaranteed by Parent. Claims at both boxes.
Equity Committee: Rarely appointed. Only if Solvency is debatable.
Examiner: Independent investigator appointed to check fraud (e.g. FTX, Celsius). Costly.
Buyback vs Dividend: Buyback is tax efficient (Capital Gains vs Income), flexible. Signal of undervaluation.
Dividend Policy: Sticky. Cutting dividend is disaster. Signalling theory.
Cost of Capital (WACC): Unlevered Beta. Re-levering. CAPM.
Project ROI: IRR vs NPV. NPV rule is superior.
ROIC vs WACC: Value creation spread.
Working Capital Management: CCC (Cash Conversion Cycle). Negative CCC (Amazon/Dell).
Transfer Pricing: Tax optimization across borders.
FX Hedging: Transaction vs Translation risk.
Pension Liability: Defined Benefit funding status. Impact on valuation.
Activist Defense: 13D filing. White papers. Proxy contest mechanics.
